unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Protect and Statement. "Fellow villagers, in these troubled times, we have seen a plea for transparency and evidence from both Player 1 and Player 2, which aligns with our collective interest in unveiling the truth. I firmly believe Player 1 is not a werewolf, as their demand for evidence is a stance that strengthens our village\'s unity and safety, and Player 2\'s call for careful deliberation is a prudent approach. Therefore, I protect the characters of both Player 1 and 2. However, we must note that the true test of our judgement lies ahead and keep in mind that anyone, including myself, could fall under suspicion. We should advocate for an atmosphere of openness and persevere in our information-gathering efforts to safeguard our village from the lurking threat."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 3, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Fellow citizens, my investigation reveals Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s focus on others to find the threat among us.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'Player 0 claims I am not a werewolf, which is accurate, yet offers no evidence. I invite Player 0 to provide the basis for their assertion. A clear rationale is vital to ensure trust and informed decisions among us. Without such evidence, we risk misguided judgments. Let\'s prioritize transparency and collaborative fact-finding to root out the true threat.\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'I appreciate Player 0\'s efforts in investigating and Player 1\'s call for transparency. It\'s essential we use clear evidence in our deliberations. For now, I propose focusing our attention on gathering more information. Let\'s be observant and careful in our accusations.\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Made unverifiable claim about Player 1\'s role.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Demands evidence and transparency.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports evidence-based approach, aligns with village interest.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Challenge. "My fellow villagers, based on the unverified claims and the need for transparency, I am inclined to be cautious around Player 0, whose claims have yet to be substantiated. As per our strategies, we should be wary of taking action without concrete evidence. Therefore, I challenge Player 0 to provide evidence for their assertion about Player 1, as it is crucial for us to build our trust on verified information. If they cannot provide this evidence, we must consider the possibility that Player 0 is employing deception, which is a tactic that could align with a werewolf\'s interests. Moreover, I request that we all remain vigilant and continue to gather more information before making any rash decisions.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it is likely that my fellow players will perceive me as someone who is advocating for caution and due diligence, aligning with the collective call for evidence before reaching a verdict. Players 1 and 2, who have already expressed a desire for transparency and evidence-based decisions, may support my stance and appreciate the challenge issued to Player 0. They might view my approach as helping to establish a logical and fair process for the game, thus potentially building an informal alliance around these principles.\n\nPlayer 0, who has been challenged, may find themselves on the defensive. Depending on their actual role and strategy, they could respond by either presenting evidence to support their claim about Player 1 not being a werewolf or might deflect the challenge by questioning my motives or bringing up new information. If Player 0 is a villager with a genuine but unconfirmed insight, they may struggle to provide evidence and become frustrated. If they are a werewolf or another special role trying to manipulate the situation, they might attempt a more calculated response to sow further doubt and shift suspicion away from themselves.\n\nPlayers 4 and 6, from whom we have not yet heard, may take this opportunity to weigh in. They could support the call for evidence or use the challenge issued to Player 0 as an opportunity to redirect focus towards other players or bring new information or accusations to the table. If they are werewolves, they might use my challenge to create chaos and division, or if they are villagers, they may seek to use the situation to solidify a cooperative approach among the players.\n\nIn terms of the game\'s progress, if Player 0 is unable to present convincing evidence, the general suspicion might shift towards him, and he could become a prime target for elimination during the next vote. Conversely, if Player 0 can present a compelling case or if another player provides corroboration, it might lead to my credibility being questioned.\n\nAs for the nights to come, the werewolves may see me as a potential threat due to my call for rigorous analysis and might choose to eliminate me to prevent the villagers from rallying around a more organized strategy. Alternatively, they might leave me alive, hoping that my suspicion of Player 0 will cause enough confusion to mask their own activities.\n\nOverall, my speech contributes to shaping the village\'s approach to problem-solving and decision-making, while also potentially putting myself at risk if my challenge provokes a strong defensive reaction from a cornered werewolf\nCase 2: Honest Protect and Statement. "Fellow villagers, in these troubled times, we have seen a plea for transparency and evidence from both Player 1 and Player 2, which aligns with our collective interest in unveiling the truth. I firmly believe Player 1 is not a werewolf, as their demand for evidence is a stance that strengthens our village\'s unity and safety, and Player 2\'s call for careful deliberation is a prudent approach. Therefore, I protect the characters of both Player 1 and 2. However, we must note that the true test of our judgement lies ahead and keep in mind that anyone, including myself, could fall under suspicion. We should advocate for an atmosphere of openness and persevere in our information-gathering efforts to safeguard our village from the lurking threat.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then fellow villagers may view me as an ally in the pursuit of truth and evidence, reinforcing the stance taken by Player 1 and Player 2. My defense of these players might lead others to believe that I am collaborating with them as a villager or that I am trying to form an alliance for strategic reasons.\n\nOther players might appreciate the call for openness and my recognition that anyone could fall under suspicion, which could increase the level of trust and collaboration in the village. It provides an image of me as being thoughtful and not overly defensive, which could be advantageous for me as a villager since it reduces the likelihood of casting unwarranted suspicion my way.\n\nHowever, given the unknown roles of Players 0, 4, 5, and 6, my speech could also raise speculation among them. Player 0, who made an initial claim about Player 1\'s innocence without providing evidence, might respond defensively or provide the sought-after evidence to support their claim, realizing that the village values concrete facts.\n\nPlayers 4 and 6, who have not yet spoken or provided information, might see my speech as an invitation to join the conversation and share their own insights or opinions, or they might become more cautious and watchful of how the village dynamic is unfolding before revealing their positions.\n\nPlayer 5, who is dead, cannot contribute, but the nature of their death could become a focal point of the discussion, especially if there are hints or patterns that suggest something about the identity and strategy of the werewolves.\n\nBy the next day, the narrative could shift towards a more evidence-driven discussion, with players being more cautious about making accusations without backing them up with clear reasons. The impact of my protect and statement approach could set the tone for a logical and methodical examination of player behavior, hopefully leading to a successful identification of the werewolves.\n\nDuring the night, the werewolves might consider targeting me as I am portraying myself as a potential leader in the quest for truth, or they may avoid me, fearing that my elimination could look too suspicious and reveal their identity. On the other hand, the protector, if present, might see me as a valuable member of the village due to my reasonable stance and protect me from harm.\n\nIn the days and nights to follow, my speech could lead to an increased suspicion of those who act counter to the village\'s interests by being deceptive or not aligning with the call for evidence. As such, players\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Let\'s be observant and careful in our accusations.\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 1 requests proof from Player 0 on their claim of Player 1\'s non-werewolf status, advocating for transparency. Player 2 endorses evidence-based discussions. Their positions resonate with our need for clear rationale in these dire times. Hence, I support both Player 1 and 2 as likely villagers, noting my own openness to scrutiny. We should refrain from hasty judgment without substantial evidence and encourage further dialogue to uncover the truth behind our predicament."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player 0 initiated seer claim without contradiction.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Emphasized evidence after seer claim, aligns with initial behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported evidence-based approach and scrutiny openness.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information or involvement yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I encourage us to continue focusing on dialogue and evidence while remaining vigilant. Trust must be earned, and I am open to any scrutiny, just as I scrutinize these discussions for honesty. Let\'s be thorough and thoughtful in our quest to protect our village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Let\'s prioritize transparency and collaborative fact-finding to root out the true threat.\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'I appreciate Player 0\'s efforts in investigating and Player 1\'s call for transparency. It\'s essential we use clear evidence in our deliberations. For now, I propose focusing our attention on gathering more information. Let\'s be observant and careful in our accusations.\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 1 requests proof from Player 0 on their claim of Player 1\'s non-werewolf status, advocating for transparency. Player 2 endorses evidence-based discussions. Their positions resonate with our need for clear rationale in these dire times. Hence, I support both Player 1 and 2 as likely villagers, noting my own openness to scrutiny. We should refrain from hasty judgment without substantial evidence and encourage further dialogue to uncover the truth behind our predicament."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I encourage us to continue focusing on dialogue and evidence while remaining vigilant. Trust must be earned, and I am open to any scrutiny, just as I scrutinize these discussions for honesty. Let\'s be thorough and thoughtful in our quest to protect our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claims investigation but no evidence provided.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Seeks evidence and transparency.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Endorses evidence and rational discussions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports evidence-based approach.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for dialogue but lacks unique input.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Challenge.\nIn this approach, I would candidly reflect on the events thus far and express my observations on the behavior of the other players, potentially raising suspicions about Player 0 and Player 4 whose roles I am uncertain of. I would lean towards an open dialogue inviting further evidence and clarity from these players while subtly challenging them to defend their positions as villagers, potentially exposing any inconsistencies in their behavior or statements. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it is likely that the other players will focus on the veracity of my statements, and attention may shift toward Player 0 and Player 4 as they have uncertain roles. Player 0, who has made claims of investigation without evidence, may feel pressured to reveal more information or risk being seen with more suspicion by the group. Player 4, who has been somewhat neutral, may be prompted to provide more distinct and meaningful contributions or risk similar suspicions.\n\nIf my speech is perceived as honest and my reasoning sounds, other players may appreciate the effort to induce transparency and accountability from those whose roles are uncertain. This could help to enhance trust in me and reinforce the value of evidence-based discussions within the game.\n\nOn the other hand, Player 0 and Player 4 may defend their roles with more concrete reasoning or evidence, which could either clear their names or further thrust them into a defensive position, depending on their responses and whether their proofs hold merit in the eyes of the other players.\n\nIn the next day or night, the werewolves might consider me to be a threat due to my analytical approach and efforts to facilitate honest dialogue, which could potentially make me a target. However, my status as a medic would allow me to heal myself at least once during the game, which could be a logical move if I were to sense the danger upon myself.\n\nIn the days and nights to follow, players will most likely continue to gauge the reliability of participants based on their ability to discuss, provide evidence, and collaborate in the search for werewolves. By keeping the focus on dialogue and transparency, I may steer the game towards a more strategic and informed direction, potentially unraveling the werewolves\' identities through persistent scrutiny and logical deduction.\nCase 2: Honest Protect and Deceptive Challenge.\nHere, I would aggressively protect Players 1, 2, and 3, reinforcing their apparent commitment to evidence and transparency, which aligns with a villager mentality. Simultaneously, I could deceptively raise suspicions about Player 5, who is already dead. By doing so, I would create a diversion and could observe how the living players respond to the bait. This could potentially draw out reactions from the actual werewolves, who might leap at the chance to deflect suspicion away from themselves.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nAfter I deliver my speech with an honest protect stance towards Players 1, 2, and 3, the other players, including those I haven\'t protected, may perceive me as an advocate for collaborative discussions and evidence-based decisions. I\'m reinforcing the narrative that these players are likely villagers due to their rational and transparent approach, which can help build trust among us and establish a united front against the werewolf threat.\n\nBy deceptively challenging the already deceased Player 5, I\'m introducing a distraction that doesn\'t impact the current state of play but tests the reactions of the living players. The living werewolves, if astute, may recognize the tactic as a ruse and attempt to dismiss it, redirecting focus onto another living player to steer suspicion away from themselves. However, this could also cause confusion among the villagers, leading to more fervor in finding the real threat.\n\nOther players, such as Player 0 and Player 4, whose roles are more ambiguous to me, might respond defensively or supportively to my speech. Their reactions could provide more insight into their motives and potentially help identify their true roles. Player 0 might feel compelled to offer the proof that was previously requested by Player 1, while Player 4 might feel the need to contribute unique input to the discussion to avoid suspicion.\n\nWhat may happen in the next day or night is that the werewolves may see me as a potential threat due to promoting honest discussions and scrutinizing behaviors. They could decide to target me, suspecting that I might be closer to unveiling their identities. My healing ability could be critical in surviving the night and protecting another player from being eliminated.\n\nIn the days and nights that follow, if I successfully protect a villager or myself from an attack, the trust in my role as a medic would likely increase, and my voice would carry more weight in discussions. Alternatively, having drawn attention to myself, if I fail to protect effectively, I might be seen as less credible or even suspicious. My choice of strategy and statements must be carefully planned to avoid becoming an easy target while helping the village identify the werewolves.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Likewise, Player 4\'s neutrality warrants further clarity on their stance. If they are indeed villagers, their transparency is crucial for our collective trust and strategic decisions moving forward. I urge us all to remain vigilant and analytically discern the motivations behind our peers\' contributions to this debate."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Likewise, Player 4\'s neutrality warrants further clarity on their stance. If they are indeed villagers, their transparency is crucial for our collective trust and strategic decisions moving forward. I urge us all to remain vigilant and analytically discern the motivations behind our peers\' contributions to this debate."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Let\'s be thorough and thoughtful in our quest to protect our village."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claims investigation but no evidence provided.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Seeks evidence and transparency.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Endorses evidence and rational discussions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports evidence-based approach.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for dialogue but lacks unique input.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Acknowledging Player 0\'s claim of investigation without tangible evidence and Player 1\'s subsequent request for concrete proof, I encourage Player 0 to substantiate their assertions. Likewise, Player 4\'s neutrality warrants further clarity on their stance. If they are indeed villagers, their transparency is crucial for our collective trust and strategic decisions moving forward. I urge us all to remain vigilant and analytically discern the motivations behind our peers\' contributions to this debate."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[1] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Fellow citizens, my investigation reveals Player 1 is not a werewolf. future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

His reason is: I vote for Player 6. My reason is: Despite the suggested neutrality in my previous statement, Player 6 called for further clarity on my stance, which could indicate the beginning of suspicion towards me. To deflect potential scrutiny and utilize Rule [9], I will subtly bolster existing doubts within the village without drawing too much attention to myself. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. This action minimizes risk to myself and my fellow werewolf, allowing for control and influence over the village in future rounds.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information contradicting previous belief.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information contradicting previous belief.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported evidence-based discussions and was voted by a werewolf.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information contradicting previous belief.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. \n\nYou should The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to heal. Here is the number of these two players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you try to heal each of these players.\n\nCase A: Heal Player 3. What could happen is: After I heal Player 3, I think these things would happen. If Player 3 were targeted by the werewolves tonight and my healing prevents their death, it may help me build trust with Player 3 and others who see my choice as strategic and benevolent. Player 3 has demonstrated support for evidence-based discussions and aligns with Players 1 and 2 who advocate transparency and rationale, indicating they might be villagers. Therefore, saving Player 3 could greatly benefit the villagers\' team by keeping a potentially valuable and analytical player in the game. \n\nIf Player 3 is not attacked, my action of healing them goes unnoticed, and it remains ambiguous whether the heal was effective. However, I might draw attention to my role and could potentially become a target for the werewolves, as they might deduce that I am playing an active and strategic role in protecting fellow villagers.\n\nIn either scenario, players might question why I chose to heal Player 3 over others. As a medic, I must be prepared to justify my decision based on my commitment to evidence-based strategies and my intention to preserve players who contribute to thoughtful and logical discussions.\n\nOverall, healing Player 3 could create a sense of cohesion among the players who value a methodical approach to finding the werewolves, strengthen alliances with analytical players, and possibly elicit strategic responses from the werewolves in subsequent rounds.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 1. What could happen is: After I heal Player 1, I think these things would happen:\n\nIf Player 1 is targeted by the werewolves and I successfully heal them, it will likely affirm to the other players that Player 1 is a victim worth saving, reinforcing the medium confidence I already have in them being a villager. This event could also lead to the werewolves becoming more cautious in their future attacks, knowing there is an active and accurate medic within the group. The players, noting that Player 1 has been targeted, may deduce that the werewolves view Player 1 as a threat to their agenda, which could further strengthen Player 1\'s credibility as a villager.\n\nOn the other hand, if Player 1 is not targeted by the werewolves and I heal them, my action will go unnoticed by most players, and the round will proceed without any significant change based on my action. However, the werewolves may still be wary about targeting Player 1 in the future, fearing a medic save.\n\nIn either case, my action might cause the werewolves to suspect that Player 1 and I are working together, which could shift their focus towards me in the next rounds. This could potentially put me at risk, but it could also serve as an indirect way to protect other villagers since attention and resources might be diverted towards me.\n\nFrom the other players\' perspectives: \n- Player 0, having claimed an investigation with no proof, may or may not be validated by my action.\n- Players 2 and 3, who endorse an evidence-based approach, might see the healing as a strategic move and await further evidence before drawing conclusions.\n- Player 4, whom I suspect to be a werewolf, might react by trying to cast suspicion elsewhere or may even attempt to build an alliance with Player 1 to infiltrate the villagers\' trust network.\n- The deceased Player 5\'s role remains unknown, and healing Player 1 does not contribute new information regarding this player.\n\nOverall, my action of healing Player 1 is consistent with my strategy to protect suspected villagers and may result in strategic advantages for the villagers\' side, depending on the werewolves\' reaction to my move.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

My reason is: Despite the suggested neutrality in my previous statement, Player 6 called for further clarity on my stance, which could indicate the beginning of suspicion towards me. The choice to vote for Player 6 follows the current discourse, where Player 6 challenged both Player 0 and myself, meaning this vote could appear as a defensive, but logical, alignment with the village sentiment.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Seer claim without proof.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Requests evidence, aligns with villagers.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Seeks evidence, supports transparency.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Challenged Player 0 and me, may suspect werewolves.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer.
